subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Names for Parameterized Tests
msgSnippet: ... With regard to what JUnit does: This code: TestCase tc = new MyTestCase( testAddition ); tc.run(); tc.run(); Will run the same test method twice on the
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> On 10/18/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
> >
> > On 10/19/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > > Me too, but it doesn't make me right :-)
> > >
> > > Your test needs to implement the interface Test for the run() trick to
> > work.
> > > Most tests don't...
> >
> > Uh?? In JUnit 3, all tests are subclasses of TestCase... which
> implements
> > Test.
>
>
> Doh. Sorry, I posted this at the end of a long day.
>
> Still, if you're calling run(), it means you already have an instance of
> your test, right? And then, the test methods will all be invoked on
> different instances than the one you invoked run() on...

With regard to what JUnit does:

This code:

TestCase tc = new MyTestCase("testAddition");
tc.run();
tc.run();

Will run the same test method twice on the same instance. A TestCase
instance represents both a class and a single method on that class. No
additional objects will be created.

However, it is not clear that any current test runner actually does
this, or should do. (This question is being addressed in other subthreads.)

Thanks,

David Saff
